slides.title: Introduction to Child Development
slides.content:
**Understanding Child Growth and Development**

As an Anganwadi worker, you will work with children aged 0-6 years.

**Growth vs Development:**
- **Growth:** Physical changes (height, weight)
- **Development:** Functional changes (skills, abilities)

**Key Areas:**
- Physical Development
- Mental/Cognitive Development
- Social Development
- Emotional Development

**Why It Matters:** Early childhood (0-6 years) is the foundation for lifelong learning and health.

slides.title: Stages of Child Development
slides.content:
**Age-wise Development Stages**

**Infancy (0-1 year):**
- Rapid physical growth
- Learns to sit, crawl, stand
- Recognizes parents
- Babbles and makes sounds

**Toddler (1-3 years):**
- Learns to walk and run
- Starts speaking words and sentences
- Explores surroundings
- Shows independence

**Preschool (3-6 years):**
- Improved motor skills
- Better language skills
- Social interaction with peers
- Ready for formal learning

**School Age (6+ years):**
- Logical thinking develops
- Reading and writing skills
- Understands rules and cooperation

slides.title: Physical Growth Milestones
slides.content:
**Important Physical Milestones**

**Birth to 3 Months:**
- Lifts head when on stomach
- Follows objects with eyes
- Grasps objects

**4 to 6 Months:**
- Rolls over
- Sits with support
- Reaches for toys

**7 to 12 Months:**
- Sits without support
- Crawls
- Stands holding support
- First steps (around 12 months)

**1 to 2 Years:**
- Walks independently
- Climbs stairs
- Kicks ball

**2 to 3 Years:**
- Runs well
- Jumps with both feet
- Pedals tricycle

**Note:** Each child develops at their own pace. These are general guidelines.

slides.title: Mental Development
slides.content:
**Cognitive Development (Brain Development)**

**Language Development:**
- 6 months: Babbling
- 12 months: First words (mama, papa)
- 18 months: 10-20 words
- 2 years: 2-word sentences
- 3 years: Full sentences
- 4-5 years: Tells stories

**Thinking Skills:**
- Recognizes colors and shapes
- Counts numbers
- Solves simple problems
- Remembers sequences
- Asks questions (Why? What? How?)

**Learning Through Play:**
- Play is how children learn
- Develops imagination
- Improves problem-solving
- Enhances creativity

**Attention Span:**
- Gradually increases with age
- 2 years: 4-6 minutes
- 4 years: 8-12 minutes
- 6 years: 12-18 minutes

slides.title: Social and Emotional Development
slides.content:
**Social Development**

**Infancy (0-1 year):**
- Smiles at familiar faces
- Shows stranger anxiety (6-8 months)
- Separation anxiety from mother

**Toddler (1-3 years):**
- Parallel play (plays alongside others)
- Shows defiance ("No!")
- Imitates adults

**Preschool (3-6 years):**
- Cooperative play
- Makes friends
- Shares toys (sometimes!)
- Understands turn-taking

**Emotional Development:**
- Expresses emotions: Happy, sad, angry, scared
- Learns to manage emotions
- Develops empathy
- Needs love and security

**Role of Caregivers:**
- Provide safe environment
- Show love and affection
- Set consistent boundaries
- Encourage positive behavior

slides.title: Fine and Gross Motor Skills
slides.content:
**Motor Skills Development**

**Gross Motor Skills (Large Movements):**

**1 Year:**
- Stands alone
- Takes first steps

**2 Years:**
- Runs
- Climbs furniture

**3 Years:**
- Pedals tricycle
- Walks up/down stairs

**4-5 Years:**
- Hops on one foot
- Catches ball

**Fine Motor Skills (Small Movements):**

**1 Year:**
- Picks up small objects
- Feeds self with fingers

**2 Years:**
- Scribbles with crayon
- Turns pages

**3 Years:**
- Copies circle
- Uses spoon well

**4-5 Years:**
- Draws person
- Uses scissors
- Writes some letters

slides.title: Factors Affecting Development
slides.content:
**What Influences Child Development?**

**Nutrition:**
- Proper nutrition is essential
- Malnutrition delays development
- Breastfeeding supports brain development

**Health:**
- Frequent illness affects growth
- Regular health checkups important
- Vaccinations prevent diseases

**Stimulation:**
- Interaction with caregivers
- Talking, playing, reading to child
- Safe toys and play materials

**Environment:**
- Safe and loving home
- Clean surroundings
- Protection from abuse and neglect

**Genetics:**
- Inherited traits
- Family patterns

**Socioeconomic Factors:**
- Poverty affects nutrition and healthcare
- Education of parents
- Family support system

slides.title: Warning Signs in Development
slides.content:
**When to Seek Help - Red Flags**

**Physical Red Flags:**
- Not sitting by 9 months
- Not walking by 18 months
- Frequent falls after learning to walk
- Very stiff or very floppy muscles

**Language Red Flags:**
- Not babbling by 12 months
- No words by 16 months
- No 2-word phrases by 2 years
- Cannot understand simple instructions

**Social/Behavioral Red Flags:**
- No eye contact
- Not interested in playing
- Does not respond to name
- Loss of previously acquired skills

**Action Required:**
- Inform parents immediately
- Refer to Anganwadi supervisor
- Arrange medical checkup
- Early intervention helps!

slides.title: Promoting Healthy Development
slides.content:
**Your Role as Anganwadi Worker**

**Nutrition Support:**
- Ensure children get supplementary nutrition
- Educate mothers about balanced diet
- Monitor growth charts

**Health Monitoring:**
- Regular weight and height measurements
- Ensure vaccinations are complete
- Identify sick children early

**Stimulation Activities:**
- Organize play activities
- Storytelling sessions
- Songs and rhymes
- Art and craft activities

**Parent Education:**
- Teach about developmental milestones
- Importance of play
- Responsive parenting
- Early learning at home

**Safe Environment:**
- Keep Anganwadi clean
- Safe toys without sharp edges
- Supervision during play

question.questionText: At what age does a child typically start walking independently?
question.explanation: Most children start walking independently around 12 months (1 year) of age. However, the normal range is 9-18 months. Each child develops at their own pace.
